ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a new way of reading and engaging with texts. Professor Levene presented us with some challenging texts, and encouraged us to read and write about by paying very close attention to the writer's argument. This was new to meI'm more used to responding to texts comparativelyso it took an adjustment, but I definitely did build skills over the semester.
I learned how to think and how to live. It was transformative.
Writing argumentative essays, reading and truly understanding literary works, finding similar themes between different works and comparing them
I became a much stronger reader and writer. It was a hard class, but taught with the goal of students becoming better learners on their own time.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is strong as an advanced seminarit works well for students who already have the reading and critical thinking skills to comprehend some very difficult texts. That created an environment where discussion was happening on a fairly high level, which I think was a strength of the course. At the same time, however, I sometimes felt that students' questions about comprehension or concerns about texts were dismissed, which created a little bit of anxiety for me. Overall, though, I think it was good for me to work through these texts and emotions under some pressure, as the experience helped me grow as a writer and thinker.
The strengths are everything. I can think of almost no weaknesses.

It would have been good to spend a bit of time explaining the expectations for the essays which were the main deliverables. Additionally, though its not necessarily a recommendation for improvement, the key learnings of the course only revealed themselves slowly over time instead of being announced upfront.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you're someone who wants a challenge and isn't too worried about grades. Professor Levene is a very tough grader, and isn't afraid to let you know where your writing is weakest, so you have to have a bit of a thick skin for this course. At the same time, if you go in with an open mind, you'll learn a lot, and I think that taking challenging courses is a great opportunity to grow.
Yes absolutely I would. If you get the chance. Take this course.

The course offers those who seek a hands off, discursive learning experience a great possibility to learn about diverse works. Those who seek a structured, teacher led course will not necessarily find it here

As with many classes, what you "get out" of Neighbors and Others (or any course with Professor Levene) is proportional to what you "put into" it. If you do your utmost (and maybe even if you don't), this course will be the best--most inspiring, most transformative, most enlivening (but perhaps also despondency-inducing)--you will ever take.
